text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section if you love to cook there's
gonna be some point where you're gonna
need to clean a week since leeks are
grown underground they get a lot of soil
trapped in between their layers and the
point is to get rid of all of it before
you start cooking there are a lot of
ways you can do this my favorite is to
just slice the leeks lengthwise and then
rinse them under running water you'll
notice that I'm keeping the root ends
still attached that's because I want to
keep the leek together while I rinse it
so that all the layers don't fall apart
into the sink use cold water and then
just let the water get in between the
layers of the leek okay this is really
anticlimactic because this leak is
incredibly clean usually you will see
lots of soil stuck right in there but
not right now now I'm just gonna slice
off the roots I'm gonna peel off the
outer layer
and then they're ready to go you could
slice them lengthwise you can slice them
crosswise but however you use them you
know that they're clean
you
